body:
There's no disagreement about getting on to python 3 but the regression is worse. I have a patch which rebase 1903 and this pr and fixes the regression. It's in my branch p3 which is currently running in Jenkins.

To get swift to build with python 3 is surely doable but it currently builds off of trusty which doesn't have the required packages installed and it was more work than I was willing to take on just to fix the regression. I suggest we open a separate issue to update the swift dockerfile.

> Does this change work in both Python 2 and 3 environments? (This is really a side question: Does OpenWhisk run the Docker action tests using both Python 2 and Python 3?)

Yes my change works for both and there are tests now for both versions of python including the Unicode tests. 
```
$ python2.7
>>> isinstance("hi", str) and isinstance("hi", bytes)
True

>>> isinstance("‚ùÑ ‚òÉ ‚ùÑ", str) and isinstance("‚ùÑ ‚òÉ ‚ùÑ", bytes)
True
```
Picked up in #2070.
Merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/3a738e63b5bf4e0b042b3f8e5e5c5c063959d4c5.

> In python 2, isinstance(string , binary) returned true. 

Yeah, in Python 2 `bytes` is a subset of `str`, so `isinstance(string, bytes)` is `True` in Python 2 and would introduce a `decode()` after #1867.  

So you're fix

```
if not isinstance(o, str):
    o = o.decode('utf-8')
```

would skip decoding in Python 2 altogether 

```
Python 2.7.13
>>> p = subprocess.Popen(['echo', '{"foo":"–∏"}'], stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE)
>>> o, e = p.communicate()
>>> type(o)
<type 'str'>
>>> isinstance(o, bytes)
True
>>> isinstance(o, str)
True
```

and always decode in Python 3

```
Python 3.5.2
>>> p = subprocess.Popen(['echo', '{"foo":"–∏"}'], stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE,)
>>> o, e = p.communicate()
>>> type(o)
<class 'bytes'>
>>> isinstance(o, bytes)
True
>>> isinstance(o, str)
False
>>> x = o.decode('utf-8')
>>> type(x)
<class 'str'>
```

So the only decoding being done is Python 3 `bytes` to `str` (unicode).  I guess we're "handling" unicode strings by not doing anything to them?  I'd be interested to see what the errors are once the regression is fixed.

> I guess we're "handling" unicode strings by not doing anything to them?

Exactly. The proxy treats them opaquely.
Instead of relying on `isinstance()`, would it work to ask `hasattr("‚ùÑ ‚òÉ ‚ùÑ", 'decode')`?

@cclauss Ordinarily, I'd agree with you about using `hasattr`, but I think @rabbah stated the only fix that passed the current tests (and fixed the regression) was if we only decode bytes to unicode in Python 3.  In Python 2, it didn't work to do any decoding, regardless of the type.   

The `if not isinstance(o, str)` check is the logic that produces this result, but it is definitely opaque to anyone reading the code.

It's a mess, but I'd still like to know what the errors were trying to decode a `str` in Python 2, because the "winter" case seems to work fine for me in straight Python:

```
Python 2.7.13
>>> o = "‚ùÑ ‚òÉ ‚ùÑ"
>>> type(o)
<type 'str'>
>>> x = "‚ùÑ ‚òÉ ‚ùÑ".decode('utf-8')
>>> x
u'\u2744 \u2603 \u2744'
>>> type(x)
<type 'unicode'>
>>> print(x)
‚ùÑ ‚òÉ ‚ùÑ
```

Here's a _theory_: the test case(s) are busted?  Perhaps embedding a unicode character in a multi-line text in Scala ([like this](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/2070/files#diff-3126a23e4a4e7b5798e46a23458e983cR77)) is doing something unexpected? Like using unicode escape characters or something that Python does not handle by default?

I highly doubt this has anything to do with the scala unit tests since the CLI integration tests also failed. If I had to take a guess, it's probably the lack of a codec defined when running using python:2. If I get a chance, I can confirm this fairly quickly although I opted for the lack of decoding when not in binary since there's no need to decode in general. This isn't arbitrary user code: the proxy is a controlled environment.

OK here's a quick update, using my [guide on how to run against the container directly](https://medium.com/openwhisk/advanced-debugging-of-openwhisk-actions-518414636932#.qzpzfqhcl) and using the `swift3action` image from my pr with the changes to restore the behavior on master:

```
-        if not isinstance(o, str):
+        if isinstance(o, bytes):
             o = o.decode('utf-8')
-        if not isinstance(e, str):
+        if isinstance(e, bytes):
             e = e.decode('utf-8')
```

```
> ./invoke.py init unicode.swift 
OK

> ./invoke.py run '{"delimiter":"‚ùÑ"}'
{
  "error": "Internal error. 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\\u2744' in position 0: ordinal not in range(128)"
}
```

Editing the action proxy to emit the stack trace shows the failure occurs on this line:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "../actionProxy/actionproxy.py", line 238, in run
    code, result = runner.run(args, runner.env(message or {}))
  File "../actionProxy/actionproxy.py", line 154, in run
    sys.stdout.write('%s\n' % line)
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\u2744' in position 0: ordinal not in range(128)
```

Further, the type of `line` just before the `sys.stdout.write` is `unicode`.

So we should override the encoding for the swift3action proxy to be utf-8. See this commit:
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/2070/commits/c03b57ee46cd7f4e47752462862ac0db1d3272f6

It would still be desirable to skip decoding for python:2 but for that, tightening the predicate is sufficient, I think. Which brings us back full circle: skipping the decoding when the type is string. Thoughts?

I rewrote the output splitting into logs and a result string in the commit: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/2070/commits/0e9302fd9e36cfa73b1809d319d46e4a2a0161e4. This avoid emmiting log lines one at time.
@dubeejw - Would you please review the .go file changes
PG3#463 started
rebased and merged in 4d4e9fdf0e9dd4493fbcb32dd50af2f9e0afb65a

@rabbah Thanks for the additional debugging.  So the Python 2 case is failing when encoding the unicode to ascii when writing to stdout.  That makes sense.

I think skipping the response decoding in Python 2 is fine.  For determining between bytes and text, we could use the `six` library, which keeps actionProxy from having to check the Python versions.

```
import six
if isinstance(obj, six.binary_type): obj.decode('utf-8')
```

https://pythonhosted.org/six/#six.binary_type
Related to #1107
Tests passed with commits above.
tests enabled in pr #2070.
Review comments addressed.

`six.string_types` should work to detect whether subprocess response is text or binary:

```
Python 2.7.13
>>> import sys, subprocess, six
>>> p = subprocess.Popen(['echo', '{"foo":"–∏"}'], stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE)
>>> o, e = p.communicate()
>>> type(o)
<type 'str'>
>>> isinstance(o, six.string_types)
True
```

```
Python 3.5.2
>>> import sys, subprocess, six
>>> p = subprocess.Popen(['echo', '{"foo":"–∏"}'], stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE)
>>> o, e = p.communicate()
>>> type(o)
<class 'bytes'>
>>> isinstance(o, six.string_types)
False
```
Forgive, but gonna /bump this @rabbah @csantanapr as we have addressed all issues raised, including bringing in P3 updates I was going to bring in on anther PR.

@paulcastro using the ibm image, reliable?

Carlos, one bit to keep in mind is we want to run the proxy with python 3 soon so we might need to independently build and publish our own swift image. In any case having the action here built from a different base is the right idea in terms of getting the separation we want. üëç

Calculating performance data for sequence actions has two problems:

1. The start and finish of markers CONTROLLER_ACTIVATION (CONTROLLER_ACTIVATION_BLOCKING) were not in sync

The above changes should fix this.

2. Because all activations inside a sequence have the same Tid, the perftool cannot relate the different marker entries to a single activation and calculate correct durations.

do we plan to adress this too ?
Look good to me - 1404, etc matches us.  We had an issue with an older clang in the base image.  Upping the version was part of our slow-down.

One other comment, this container is Swift 3.0.2. Per issue #2079 I'd like to upgrade to Swift 3.1 and also move to the new implementation of the  associated Watson SDKs.  A PG build indicates the #2079 upgrade (?) may exacerbate the existing startup cost for the first swift3action container tests.
@csantanapr, looks like this one can be closed.
@rabbah, this issue can be closed.

@paulcastro I want to do the change gradually, I purposely didn't update to swift 3.1 and updated the WatsonSDK and JSON lib to latest. 
I think that should be done in a separate PR

Also @rabbah I think we need to deprecate the use of a single swift file for swift actions.
I think we should restrict to only accepting swift zip precompiled actions. 
This will avoid users to hit a very large cold start by mistake, and also reduce the docker image size were we can use `ibmcon/swift-ubuntu-runtime` and cut the size of the image.
we can debate that separately: if we add the _init_ actions, then users can get that for free.

That was my thinking also, but from the perspective of the runtime it only takes zip
Even it means the init actions are helpers to get the zip created/refreshed

@paulcastro 
When you have a chance can you try this PR.
The image is not being built correctly
This step:
```
 python /swift3Action/buildandrecord.py
Building action
action built. Decoding compile and link commands
Cannot generate build script: compile or link command not found
root@63e23669742f:/swift3Action/spm-build# echo $?
1
```
I'm testing it now - good catch.  I noticed that the home directory gets set to the swift runtime instead of "/"

fetch again I made an update to make it `/`

the ibmcon/swift-ubuntu image sets the workdir to /root
@paulcastro https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/2085/commits/bb9d21037e7c7d21f67f83ff3c5b0e265b3f9a10

`swiftc` is in a different location so lines 26 and 27 of buildandrecord.py should be:

```
COMPILE_PREFIX = "/root/swift-3.0.2-RELEASE-ubuntu14.04/usr/bin/swiftc -module-name Action "
LINKER_PREFIX = "'/root/swift-3.0.2-RELEASE-ubuntu14.04/usr/bin/swiftc' -Xlinker '-rpath=$ORIGIN' '-L/swift3Action/spm-build/.build/release' -o '/swift3Action/spm-build/.build/release/Action'"
```

I have an example in my 3.1 [branch](https://github.com/paulcastro/openwhisk/blob/issue_2079b-x/core/swift3Action/buildandrecord.py)
Thanks @paulcastro that did the trick https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/2085/commits/33ef2959b69bea6d8873924eb99b89578b38d5a5

PG2/1367 üîµ

@rabbah take a look https://travis-ci.org/openwhisk/openwhisk/builds/217642278

It took 48 minutes and this is without the docker push deploy step. 
I have measure push step on my fork and the step takes around 5 minutes. 

Which tests could we ignore for now  to gain those 5 minutes?

We could enable the tests in near future by cutting the deployment time by other means
Do not build CLI , and just curl a Linux binary from another the sperate repo
Move based runtimes to another repo keeping only proxyaction in this repo
Add Jenkins in Public Apache and have it do builds for PRs that can take longer with full suite of tests

What is more important for us at the moment? Sufficient test coverage or the Dockerhub based images? The first round of ignoring stuff was merely a measure to even get below 50minutes again and was by no means a practice that we should continue doing. The problem is not the 50minutes limit of Travis, the problem is how we waste our own time with such long build/test cycles.
PG1 1346 üîµ
Can the push script run as a second Travis build iff the first build succeeds?

I enabled more tests in pr #2070 because it was misleading to contributors who were making python/swift related changes. So with 2070 and this pr it sounds like we will be over the limit again. So we should look at doing better.
PG2#1363 is green.
I would still be interested in a discussion on the [use of the builtin venv vs virtualenv](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1940#issuecomment-284425619) now that Python 3 is the default.

the action dependencies can be an optional overlay archive, that get's extracted first, then extract the actions main/exec archive. Then API should allow to only update one or the other, but still the action revision/version as a whole would get bump to a new one. 
This would allow in the future we change the runtime bits, user or system, or tooling can detect the change and redo the dependency zip by re-creating the node_modules from scratch using the new runtime (which could be a new linux i.e. ubuntu 14 to ubuntu16)
PG1#1349 is green

I implemented one little change:
If an invoker registers at the controller, it starts with UnHealthy instead of Healthy.
The reason is to recognise a potential failure of the test action, that brings up the invoker again, as soon as possible.
Would be great thomas! Meanwhile, how can I access the remaining results?

@csantanapr, the minimum and maximums should be added to all command (action, trigger, etc...) flags that take numeric input.  The only issue is that we can't include the min and max in parentheses with the default as that text is generated by a package we utilize to parse arguments. We'd have to do something that would look like this `only return `LIMIT` number of activations from the collection (min 1, max 200) (default 30)`

@dubeejw - Thanks for the comments.  I believe I've responded to all of them.  Any other comments?

it would nice if this is done to avoid hard coding any of these values in the cli directly - to avoid going out of sync with the api/backend.

some limits (and supported runtimes) will soon be available as part of pr #1980; we could consider adding more here, or reading the info from the swagger where appropriate.

i would like to avoid a repeat of the schema getting out of sync with the backend with bit us repeatedly until some of it was removed.
+1 drive thru configuration, do not hard code numbers if possible.
Hmm, sounds like we will have to query the backend for limits when the help commands are invoked.
